title: EPF North Star Schema
description: Schema for validating North Star documents that capture organizational strategic foundation - the enduring context that informs all EPF cycles. North Star is relatively stable (reviewed yearly or when major pivots occur) and provides the strategic lens through which all other EPF artifacts (READY, FIRE, AIM) are evaluated.
$comment: North Star YAML files live in templates/READY/ or _instances/{product}/00_north_star.yaml. They document WHY the organization exists (Purpose), WHERE it's headed (Vision), WHAT it does (Mission), HOW it operates (Values), and WHAT IT BELIEVES (Core Beliefs). North Star is foundational - it doesn't change with quarterly plans or feature priorities. Use North Star to: (1) Align strategy decisions - does this opportunity serve our purpose? (2) Evaluate trade-offs - which value takes priority? (3) Test beliefs - is the market evolving as we expected? (4) Onboard leaders - what makes us different? North Star is living - update when pivots occur, but don't chase trends. Tools can validate internal consistency (does mission serve purpose?) and track evolution over time.

purpose.description: Why the organization exists - the fundamental reason for being that transcends products, markets, and strategies.
purpose.$comment: Purpose answers 'Why do we exist beyond making money?' It defines the problem worth solving and the impact worth creating. Purpose is the most stable element of North Star (rarely changes). Use purpose to: (1) Test strategic opportunities - does this serve our purpose? (2) Inspire teams - what bigger impact are we creating? (3) Guide pivots - our HOW may change, but our WHY endures. Purpose statements are emotional and aspirational (not dry mission statements). Example: 'To democratize access to legal services' (purpose) vs 'We provide legal software' (mission). Tools can validate that mission and strategy serve the purpose.

statement.description: Clear, inspiring statement of why the organization exists. Should be emotional, aspirational, and timeless. Avoid describing what you do (that's mission) - focus on why it matters. Example: 'To empower every person to achieve their health potential' or 'To make the world's information universally accessible'
statement.$comment: Purpose statement is the North Star of your North Star. Write it for customers, employees, investors - anyone who asks 'why should I care?' Format: 'To [action verb] [whom/what] [desired outcome/state]'. Test: If you pivoted products tomorrow, would this purpose still apply? If no, it's too specific. Length: 20-200 chars keeps it memorable and shareable.

problem_we_solve.description: The fundamental problem being addressed - the pain, gap, or injustice that motivates your existence. Describe the world's current state that you find unacceptable. Example: 'Legal services are unaffordable and inaccessible for 80% of people, leaving them vulnerable to exploitation' or 'Climate data is fragmented across silos, preventing coordinated action'
problem_we_solve.$comment: This is the 'burning platform' - what breaks if you don't exist? Frame as: (1) Current state (what's wrong), (2) Who suffers (specific people/groups), (3) Why it matters (consequences). Avoid solution-speak ('lack of software') - describe the human/business problem ('people can't access justice'). Cross-reference: This problem informs all READY phase insights and opportunities.

who_we_serve.description: Broadest definition of beneficiaries - who benefits from solving this problem. Cast a wide net (you'll narrow in mission). Example: 'Small businesses, entrepreneurs, and everyday people navigating legal systems' or 'Climate scientists, policymakers, and activists worldwide'
who_we_serve.$comment: Purpose-level serving is expansive (mission will be specific). Think stakeholder ecosystem: direct users, indirect beneficiaries, society at large. Use inclusive language ('everyone,' 'any person') when genuinely universal, otherwise specify ('underserved communities,' 'knowledge workers'). This defines your potential market ceiling - mission will define today's beachhead.

impact_we_seek.description: Ultimate change desired in the world - the future state if you succeed wildly. Describe societal/industry transformation, not company metrics. Example: 'A world where everyone has equal access to justice, regardless of wealth' or 'A global community acting in coordinated response to climate challenges'
impact_we_seek.$comment: Impact is your 'dent in the universe' - what changes in the world beyond your company? Frame at scale: if you 10x'd or became the dominant solution, what shifts? This is NOT vision (that's about YOUR future) - this is about THE WORLD'S future. Tools can validate: Does strategy/roadmap work toward this impact? Does mission deliver on this promise?

vision.description: Vivid picture of YOUR future (5-10 years) - what success looks like for your organization specifically. Vision is where you're headed; purpose is why you exist.
vision.$comment: Vision paints a concrete future state for YOUR organization (not the world - that's impact). Good vision: (1) Time-bound (5-10 years), (2) Observable (you'll know when you've arrived), (3) Ambitious but believable, (4) Differentiating (not generic). Vision vs Purpose: Purpose is eternal ('why we exist'), Vision evolves ('where we're going now'). Update vision when: hitting milestones, pivoting strategy, or when current vision achieved. Tools can track: Are we on pace? Has vision shifted? What changed and why?

vision_statement.description: Vivid picture of the future (5-10 years) showing where your organization will be. Paint a scene: market position, capabilities, reputation, scale. Example: 'We are the trusted platform for 1M small businesses, recognized globally as the gold standard for accessible legal services' or 'We are the central hub connecting all climate data sources, used by every major policy body'
vision_statement.$comment: Vision statement should pass the 'time machine test': if you landed in 2030, what would you SEE? Avoid vague ('world-class,' 'leading') - be specific ('serving 10M users in 50 countries,' '80% market share in SMB legal tech'). Format: 'We are [market position] [scale metric], [known for] [differentiation]'. Length 50-300 chars forces clarity. This is your rallying cry for the next 5-10 years.

timeframe.description: Vision timeframe - either single year (2030) or range (2025-2030). Should be 5-10 years out for big ambitions but realistic planning. Example: '2030' or '2025-2030'
timeframe.$comment: Most visions target 5-10 years: far enough for transformative change, near enough to feel real. Format: 'YYYY' or 'YYYY-YYYY'. Avoid open-ended ('by 2030+') - commitment requires specificity. Update timeframe when rolling forward (2025 vision becomes 2030 vision) or pivoting timeline. Pattern validates YYYY format.

success_looks_like.description: Observable indicators of vision achievement - concrete, measurable signs you've arrived. Mix quantitative (metrics) and qualitative (reputation, capabilities). Example: ['1M active users across 50 countries', 'Recognized as category leader by Gartner', 'Operating profitably with 40%+ margins', 'Team of 500+ with <10% annual turnover']
success_looks_like.$comment: Success indicators make vision falsifiable: in 2030, you can check these off. Include: (1) Scale metrics (users, revenue, markets), (2) Market position (rankings, awards, analyst recognition), (3) Financial health (profitability, margins), (4) Team/culture (size, retention, quality), (5) Capability (product maturity, tech leadership). Aim for 3-10 indicators spanning different dimensions. Each indicator should be independently observable - no compound metrics. Tools can track progress: which indicators are we hitting? Where are we behind?

not_the_vision.description: Clarifications on what we're NOT trying to become - explicit anti-visions to prevent scope creep and maintain focus. Example: ['NOT becoming a full-service law firm', 'NOT competing in consumer legal tech', 'NOT building hardware devices', 'NOT pursuing acquisition-driven growth at expense of product']
not_the_vision.$comment: Anti-vision sets boundaries: what tempting paths will we NOT take? This prevents: (1) Scope creep (exciting tangents that dilute focus), (2) Mission drift (opportunities misaligned with purpose), (3) Stakeholder confusion ('I thought you were building X'). Common anti-visions: adjacent markets (tempting but off-strategy), business models (don't want to be services company), growth tactics (won't sacrifice quality for speed). Update when new temptations arise or when stakeholders keep asking 'why not X?' Aim for 1-5 - enough to set boundaries, not so many it feels restrictive.

mission.description: What we do and for whom - the operational expression of purpose. Mission is more specific than purpose (describes HOW), more stable than strategy (describes WHAT), and evolves as capabilities grow.
mission.$comment: Mission bridges eternal purpose ('why') and dynamic strategy ('how right now'). Good mission: (1) Actionable (describes what you DO), (2) Specific (clear target customers/segments), (3) Differentiating (not generic 'we build software'), (4) Bounded (explicit scope). Mission vs Purpose: Purpose says 'democratize legal services' (aspiration), Mission says 'provide self-service legal docs for SMBs' (implementation). Update mission when: entering new markets, adding product lines, pivoting ICP. Tools can validate: Does product roadmap deliver on mission? Does mission serve purpose?

mission_statement.description: Clear statement of WHAT we do and FOR WHOM. Should be specific enough to guide decisions but broad enough to allow innovation. Example: 'We provide self-service legal document automation for small businesses navigating contracts, employment, and compliance' or 'We connect climate data sources into a unified platform for researchers and policymakers'
mission_statement.$comment: Mission statement format: 'We [action verb] [solution/offering] for [specific customer] [specific jobs/outcomes]'. Test: Can a stranger understand what you sell and who buys it? If no, too abstract. Can you pivot products without changing mission? If no, too specific. Length 30-250 chars forces clarity without excessive detail. This is your elevator pitch foundation.

what_we_do.description: Core activities - the 3-5 essential things you do that deliver your mission. Example: ['Generate legal documents from templates', 'Connect users with vetted lawyers for review', 'Maintain compliance tracking and alerts', 'Provide legal education resources']
what_we_do.$comment: Core activities are your value creation engine. Include: (1) Product/service delivery (what customers buy), (2) Support activities (enable delivery), (3) Differentiated capabilities (do better than alternatives). Aim for 2-7 activities - enough to show breadth, few enough to stay focused. Each activity should be: Observable (you can see it happening), Resource-consuming (takes time/money/people), Value-creating (customers care). Avoid: Internal ops (HR, finance) unless they're differentiators, Future aspirations (that's roadmap), Generic fluff ('delight customers'). Tools can map: Which Value Model components deliver these activities?

how_we_deliver.description: Distinctive approach and key capabilities - what makes your delivery different/better than alternatives.
how_we_deliver.$comment: This is your unfair advantage: the HOW that's hard to copy. Capture both approach (philosophy/methodology) and capabilities (what you're uniquely good at). Example approaches: 'AI-first document generation' (technology), 'White-glove concierge model' (service), 'Open-source community-driven' (business model). Example capabilities: 'Natural language processing of legal text,' 'Network of 10K+ vetted lawyers,' 'Real-time compliance monitoring.' Update when: acquiring new capabilities, changing delivery model, discovering new differentiators.

approach.description: Distinctive approach or methodology - your philosophy of delivery. What makes your HOW different? Example: 'AI-powered automation with human expert review - combining speed of technology with judgment of experienced lawyers' or 'Community-driven open-source platform where researchers contribute and validate data collaboratively'
approach.$comment: Approach is your delivery philosophy. Good approach statements: (1) Differentiated (not table stakes), (2) Defensible (hard to copy), (3) Aligned with values (how you choose to operate). Avoid: Generic ('customer-focused quality'), Buzzwords without substance ('leveraging synergies'), Pure technology (unless truly differentiated). Frame as: '[unique element] with/for [outcome] that [alternatives] can't/don't provide.' Length 30-300 chars prevents vagueness.

key_capabilities.description: Key capabilities that enable your approach - the 3-6 things you're uniquely good at. Example: ['Natural language processing of legal documents', 'Network of 10K+ pre-vetted lawyers', 'Real-time compliance monitoring engine', 'Multi-jurisdiction legal knowledge base']
key_capabilities.$comment: Capabilities are what you CAN DO that others can't (easily). Good capabilities: (1) Rare (not widely available), (2) Valuable (customers care), (3) Inimitable (hard to copy), (4) Organized (you actually leverage them). Sources: technology (IP, algorithms), relationships (networks, partnerships), knowledge (domain expertise), process (operating efficiency), brand (reputation, trust). Aim for 2-8 capabilities. Map to Value Model: capabilities should enable value paths. Update when: acquiring/building new capabilities, discovering underutilized strengths, losing capability through attrition.

who_we_serve_specifically.description: Specific segments, roles, or personas - your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP). Narrower than purpose-level 'who_we_serve'. Example: 'Small businesses (5-50 employees) in high-compliance industries (healthcare, finance, real estate) who need frequent contract review but can't afford in-house counsel' or 'Climate researchers at universities and NGOs who aggregate data from multiple sources for policy analysis'
who_we_serve_specifically.$comment: This is your beachhead: who you serve FIRST/BEST today. Balance: Specific enough to focus (can visualize personas), broad enough to scale (addressable market >$100M). Include: Company size/stage, Industry/vertical, Role/title, Geography (if relevant), Psychographics (early adopter, cost-conscious, quality-focused). Avoid: 'Anyone who needs X' (too broad), 'Enterprise Fortune 500' (if you're not there yet). Test: Can sales use this to qualify leads? Can marketing target ads? Update when: achieving product-market fit in new segment, discovering better-fit ICP, expanding upmarket/downmarket.

boundaries.description: Explicit boundaries defining what's out of scope - helps maintain focus and manage stakeholder expectations.
boundaries.$comment: Boundaries prevent mission creep: the tempting adjacencies you'll say NO to. This is strategic refusal: choosing NOT to do things that seem logical but dilute focus. Common boundaries: Adjacent products (consumer vs B2B, hardware vs software), Services (consulting, implementation), Geographies (global vs regional), Customer segments (SMB vs Enterprise). Update boundaries when: repeatedly asked 'why don't you do X?', seeing competitors succeed in spaces you're avoiding (reconsider), discovering new adjacencies (add to 'we don't do').

we_dont_do.description: List of things explicitly out of scope. Example: ['Full-service law firm representation', 'Consumer legal tech (divorce, wills)', 'Custom software development for legal ops', 'Legal content publishing/education']
we_dont_do.$comment: Explicit 'no' list helps teams filter opportunities quickly. Each boundary should be: Tempting (otherwise why mention?), Clear (no ambiguity), Defensible (you can explain why not). Format: What you don't do + why it matters. Aim for 1-7 boundaries. This is your 'focus filter' for product, partnerships, and hiring.

why_not.description: Strategic rationale for boundaries - why these choices maintain focus. Example: 'We don't pursue consumer legal tech because SMB market offers 10x TAM with less competition. We don't do custom software because productization is our differentiator. We avoid full-service representation to maintain capital efficiency and scalability.'
why_not.$comment: Rationale makes boundaries defensible: you're not just saying no, you're explaining why NO serves the mission better. Good rationale references: Market size (bigger opportunity elsewhere), Competitive advantage (stay in our lane), Resource constraints (can't do everything), Strategic focus (builds on strengths). This section helps board/team understand trade-offs. Update when rationale shifts (market changes, capabilities grow).

values.description: Core values defining how the organization operates - the behavioral standards and cultural principles that guide decisions, hiring, and day-to-day operations. Values should be observable (you can see when someone lives them or violates them), aspirational (north star for behavior), and differentiating (not table stakes).
values.$comment: Values are your culture codified: the behaviors you hire for, promote by, and fire over. Good values are: (1) Observable - clear behaviors you expect/reject, (2) Tested - examples of value-driven decisions, (3) Non-negotiable - you'll sacrifice short-term gains to uphold them. Values should feel HARD: if they're easy to live by, they're not values - they're hygiene. Most organizations have 3-7 core values. Use values to: (1) Hiring - screen for value fit in interviews, (2) Performance - incorporate into reviews and feedback, (3) Decisions - reference when facing trade-offs or conflicts. Update values when: Culture evolves (rare, 3-5 year cycle), Scaling reveals gaps (values that worked at 10 people fail at 100), Leadership changes (new CEO may shift culture).

value.description: Value name - concise label for the principle. Should be memorable and distinctive. Examples: 'Bias to Action', 'Customer-First', 'Radical Transparency', 'Earn Trust', 'Think Long-Term', 'Disagree and Commit'
value.$comment: Value names should be: Memorable (1-4 words), Specific (not generic 'Integrity'), Action-oriented (verb-based or implies behavior), Ownable (differentiated from competitors). Avoid: Generic platitudes ('Respect', 'Excellence'), Buzzwords ('Innovation', 'Synergy'), Descriptions (too long - use definition for that). Test: Can you wear it on a t-shirt without cringing? If yes, good value name.

definition.description: What this value means in practice - behavioral translation of the principle. Define in terms of observable actions, not abstract ideals. Example for 'Bias to Action': 'We prefer fast decisions with incomplete information over slow decisions with perfect data. We celebrate smart experiments that fail. We default to "yes" unless there's a compelling reason to say "no".'
definition.$comment: Definition bridges abstract value and concrete behavior. Good definition: (1) Actionable - describes what people DO, (2) Specific - situations where value applies, (3) Tested - you can assess if someone embodies it, (4) Contextual - acknowledges when value doesn't apply. Format: What [value] means + How it shows up + When it matters most. Avoid abstract language ('commitment to quality') - use behavioral anchors ('we ship MVPs and iterate based on feedback'). Definition should pass the 'new hire test': can someone who joined yesterday understand what behavior you expect?

behaviors_we_expect.description: Specific behaviors that demonstrate this value - observable actions that exemplify living the value. These are your 'green flags' in hiring, performance reviews, and feedback.
behaviors_we_expect.$comment: Expected behaviors are your hiring screen and performance criteria. Each behavior should be: Observable (you can see it), Specific (clear action, not vague trait), Common enough (happens regularly, not edge cases), Testable (interview questions can surface). Aim for 2-6 behaviors per value. Sources: Interview question answers ('tell me about a time...'), Performance review themes (top performers consistently do X), Culture moments (stories told about heroes). Format: [Action verb] [specific behavior] [context]. Example: 'Shares work-in-progress openly even when incomplete', 'Challenges decisions respectfully when they see risks', 'Ships small increments weekly instead of waiting for perfection'.

behaviors_we_reject.description: Specific behaviors that violate this value - observable actions that contradict the value. These are your 'red flags' and reasons for feedback, warnings, or termination.
behaviors_we_reject.$comment: Rejected behaviors define boundaries: what will NOT be tolerated even if it delivers results. Each behavior should be: Observable (you can catch it), Serious (worth addressing), Clear (no ambiguity on violation). Aim for 1-5 per value - focus on most common/damaging violations. These behaviors should trigger: Immediate feedback (manager addresses), Performance improvement plan (if repeated), Termination (if egregious or uncoachable). Format: [Action/pattern] [specific violation] [consequence]. Example: 'Hoards information to maintain personal leverage', 'Waits for perfect plan before starting work', 'Criticizes decisions without offering alternatives'. Red flags help with: Exit decisions (when to let someone go), Feedback clarity (this is the line you crossed), Hiring filters (behavioral interview questions to screen out).

example_decision.description: Concrete example where this value guided a real decision - story illustrating the value in action, ideally with trade-offs and consequences. Example: 'When deciding between two product features, we chose the one customers asked for (even though the other was technically more interesting) because Customer-First means we build what they need, not what we want to build. We lost an engineer who wanted the cool problem, but gained faster revenue.'
example_decision.$comment: Example decisions are teaching tools: stories that show VALUES > SHORT-TERM GAINS. Good examples include: (1) Context (what was the choice?), (2) Conflict (what made it hard? what did you sacrifice?), (3) Choice (how did value guide decision?), (4) Consequence (what happened? was it worth it?). Best examples are: Recent (last 1-2 years), Costly (real sacrifice, not easy choice), Attributable (value clearly drove decision, not other factors), Celebrated (story told repeatedly in onboarding/all-hands). Sources: Leadership decisions (CEO/exec choices), Product/strategy pivots (changed direction based on value), Hiring/firing (passed on great candidate because values misfit, let go high performer who violated values). Update examples periodically - fresh stories keep values alive.

value_conflicts.description: Common tensions between values - situations where two values pull in opposite directions. Documenting these conflicts with resolution principles helps teams navigate trade-offs consistently.
value_conflicts.$comment: Value conflicts are inevitable: Speed vs Quality, Innovation vs Stability, Customer-First vs Employee-First, Transparency vs Confidentiality. Good conflict documentation: (1) Acknowledges tension (values genuinely conflict), (2) Provides resolution framework (how to decide), (3) Gives examples (when each value wins). Most organizations have 1-5 documented conflicts. Use conflicts to: (1) Decision-making (when stuck between values, reference resolution principle), (2) Onboarding (teach new hires how to navigate dilemmas), (3) Post-mortems (when decision backfires, did we apply resolution correctly?). Update when: New conflicts emerge (scaling reveals tensions you didn't have before), Resolution principles fail (team consistently disagrees with documented approach), Values evolve (new value introduces new tension).

tension.description: Description of the value conflict - which two values pull in opposite directions and in what situations. Example: 'Bias to Action (ship fast) conflicts with Think Long-Term (build for scale) when deciding MVP scope: do we ship minimal feature now or wait to build right architecture?'
tension.$comment: Tension should be: Real (actually comes up in decisions, not theoretical), Balanced (both values are legitimate, not one obviously wrong), Common (happens frequently enough to warrant documentation). Format: [Value A] conflicts with [Value B] when [situation]. Example conflicts by growth stage: Early stage: Speed vs Quality (ship MVP vs build it right), Mid stage: Autonomy vs Alignment (move fast vs coordinate), Late stage: Innovation vs Efficiency (experiment vs optimize). Test: Does your team debate this trade-off regularly? If yes, document it. If no, it's not a real conflict (yet).

resolution_principle.description: How to resolve when these values conflict - the decision framework or hierarchy to apply. Example: 'When Speed conflicts with Long-Term, default to Speed for customer-facing MVPs (learn fast) but Long-Term for platform/infrastructure (pays off compound). Ask: Is this reversible? If yes, bias to action. If no (hard to undo), think long-term. Over time, shift: Early stage → Speed wins 80% of time. Growth stage → Context-dependent. Mature → Long-term wins 60% of time.'
resolution_principle.$comment: Resolution principle is your tie-breaker: when both values matter, which wins and when? Good resolution: (1) Contextual (depends on situation - customer vs internal, reversible vs irreversible), (2) Hierarchical (one value trumps in certain contexts), (3) Phased (resolution shifts over time as company matures), (4) Testable (after decision, can evaluate if we applied correctly). Avoid false absolutes ('Speed always wins') - nuance is the point. Format: Default [Value X] when [context], but [Value Y] when [different context]. Decision heuristics: Reversibility (easy to undo → bias to speed), Impact (high stakes → bias to quality), Audience (customer-facing → bias to user needs, internal → bias to efficiency). Reference in: 1-on-1s (manager helps report navigate dilemma), Retrospectives (did we apply principle correctly?), All-hands (teach resolution framework).

core_beliefs.description: Fundamental assumptions about market, users, approach, value creation, and competition that inform strategy. These beliefs should be testable hypotheses, not immutable truths - regularly validate and update based on evidence.
core_beliefs.$comment: Core beliefs are your strategic assumptions: the 'truths' that drive your strategy. Good beliefs: (1) Explicit (written down, not implicit), (2) Testable (you could prove them wrong), (3) Consequential (if wrong, strategy changes), (4) Evidence-based (anchored in data/research, not wishful thinking). Use beliefs to: (1) Strategy validation (do insights confirm or challenge our beliefs?), (2) Decision frameworks (if we believe X, then we should do Y), (3) Risk identification (what if we're wrong?). Update beliefs during: Calibration (quarterly check: still true?), Major pivots (changing strategy likely means changing beliefs), Post-mortems (strategy failed - which belief was wrong?). Beliefs should be organized by category for clarity. Reference in: Strategy sessions (do proposed initiatives align with beliefs?), Board decks (here's what we believe about the world), Onboarding (here's why we do what we do).

about_our_market.description: Beliefs about market dynamics, trends, and structure. Example: 'Legal services market is shifting from hourly billing to value-based pricing', 'SMB legal spend will grow 15% CAGR as compliance complexity increases', 'Winners will have integrated workflows, not point solutions'.
about_our_market.$comment: Market beliefs inform WHERE to compete (which segments, which geographies, which problems). Focus on: Market size/growth (TAM trends), Buyer behavior (how decisions are made, who holds budget), Market structure (fragmented vs consolidated, emerging vs mature), Regulatory/macro trends (tailwinds or headwinds). Aim for 1-5 market beliefs. Test market beliefs against: Industry reports (Gartner, Forrester, CB Insights), Customer interviews (do they see the same trends?), Competitor behavior (are they betting on same shifts?). Update when: Market data contradicts belief (TAM smaller than thought), Customer behavior shifts (buying process changes), Regulatory changes (new compliance requirements).

belief.description: The market assumption - what you believe to be true about market dynamics, customer behavior, or industry trends.

implication.description: Strategic consequence if belief is true - how this belief shapes your strategy, positioning, or roadmap. Example: 'If legal market shifts to value-based pricing, we must build ROI measurement into our product and train sales to sell outcomes (time saved, risk reduced) not features.'

evidence.description: Data or research supporting this belief - industry reports, customer interviews, market analysis, or observed trends. Example: '3 of 5 target customers mentioned budget pressure to justify legal spend. Thomson Reuters 2023 report shows 40% of law departments exploring value-based billing. 2 competitors launched pricing calculators in last 6 months.'

about_our_users.description: Beliefs about user needs, behaviors, and motivations. Example: 'In-house counsel prioritize risk mitigation over cost savings', 'Legal ops teams are more tech-savvy than traditional lawyers', 'Users will adopt software that saves them 5+ hours/week even if UI is rough'.
about_our_users.$comment: User beliefs inform WHAT to build (product priorities, feature set). Focus on: User motivations (what drives decisions - fear, ambition, efficiency?), Adoption barriers (why users resist change), Jobs to be done (functional, emotional, social jobs), Behavioral patterns (how users actually work vs how you wish they worked). Aim for 1-5 user beliefs. Test user beliefs through: User interviews (qualitative), Usage analytics (quantitative), Usability testing (observational), Churn analysis (why do users leave?). Update when: Usage data contradicts belief (users don't behave as expected), Customer feedback shifts (new pain points emerge), Persona mix changes (different user types join).

belief.description: The user assumption - what you believe about user needs, behaviors, motivations, or decision-making.

implication.description: Product/UX consequence if belief is true - how this shapes features, onboarding, or user experience design.

evidence.description: User research or data supporting this belief - interviews, surveys, analytics, usability tests.

about_our_approach.description: Beliefs about HOW you should deliver value - your delivery philosophy, go-to-market strategy, or operational model. Example: 'Product-led growth outperforms sales-led in SMB legal tech', 'Community-driven content generates higher-quality leads than paid ads', 'Vertical depth (legal-specific) beats horizontal breadth (general workflow tool)'.
about_our_approach.$comment: Approach beliefs inform HOW to execute (GTM strategy, product delivery, ops model). Focus on: GTM motion (PLG vs sales-led, inbound vs outbound), Product strategy (vertical vs horizontal, integrated vs best-of-breed), Operational model (build vs buy vs partner, in-house vs outsourced), Moats (network effects, data, brand, integrations). Aim for 1-5 approach beliefs. Test approach beliefs through: GTM experiments (try different motions, measure CAC/conversion), Competitor analysis (what's working for others?), Unit economics (does approach scale profitably?). Update when: GTM results contradict belief (PLG isn't working), Competitive dynamics shift (new entrant changes game), Unit economics break (approach doesn't scale).

belief.description: The approach assumption - what you believe about optimal go-to-market, product delivery, or operational strategy.

implication.description: Execution consequence if belief is true - how this shapes GTM motion, product roadmap, or organizational structure.

evidence.description: Data or case studies supporting this belief - internal metrics, competitor benchmarks, industry best practices.

about_value_creation.description: Beliefs about what creates value for customers and how you capture it. Example: 'Customers value time savings 3x more than cost savings', 'Workflow integration creates more value than standalone tools', 'Freemium users convert at 5% if we nail onboarding'.
about_value_creation.$comment: Value creation beliefs inform PRICING and PACKAGING (how to monetize). Focus on: Value drivers (what customers care about most - time, risk, quality?), Willingness to pay (price anchors, budget holders), Monetization model (subscription, usage-based, transaction), Value capture (do we capture value proportional to value created?). Aim for 1-5 value beliefs. Test value creation beliefs through: Pricing experiments (A/B test packaging, measure conversion), Customer interviews (what would you pay? what drives ROI?), Win/loss analysis (why do deals close or fall apart?), Retention cohorts (do customers renew? expand?). Update when: Pricing experiments show different WTP (customers pay more/less than expected), Value perception shifts (features that mattered become table stakes), Competitive pricing changes (market resets expectations).

belief.description: The value assumption - what you believe about customer value drivers, willingness to pay, or monetization.

implication.description: Pricing/packaging consequence if belief is true - how this shapes pricing model, packaging, or sales strategy.

evidence.description: Customer research or revenue data supporting this belief - pricing tests, customer interviews, revenue analysis.

about_competition.description: Beliefs about competitive dynamics, threats, and defensibility. Example: 'Incumbents are too slow to adapt to AI disruption', 'Vertical SaaS tools will consolidate into platforms (we should build ecosystem)', 'Network effects don't apply to legal tech (switching costs are the moat)'.
about_competition.$comment: Competition beliefs inform MOAT building and DEFENSIBILITY strategy. Focus on: Competitive threats (who can disrupt us? what's our vulnerability?), Defensibility sources (network effects, data moat, brand, switching costs), Market positioning (blue ocean vs red ocean, niche vs broad), Competitive response (how will incumbents/entrants react to our moves?). Aim for 1-5 competition beliefs. Test competition beliefs through: Competitive intelligence (track competitor moves, fundraising, customer reviews), Customer interviews (who else did you consider? why us?), Win/loss analysis (when do we win/lose and why?), Market share tracking (are we gaining or losing ground?). Update when: Competitive landscape shifts (new entrant, incumbent moves downmarket), Customer feedback changes ("you're no longer differentiated"), Defensibility proves weaker/stronger than expected.

belief.description: The competitive assumption - what you believe about competitors, market positioning, or defensibility.

implication.description: Strategic consequence if belief is true - how this shapes competitive positioning, moat building, or market expansion.

evidence.description: Competitive intelligence or market analysis supporting this belief - competitor tracking, analyst reports, customer feedback.

belief_challenges.description: Known challenges to beliefs - counter-evidence or scenarios that would invalidate core beliefs. Documenting challenges demonstrates intellectual honesty and helps identify monitoring metrics.
belief_challenges.$comment: Belief challenges are 'what could prove us wrong?' - the falsification criteria for your strategy. Good challenges: (1) Specific (clear counter-evidence, not vague doubts), (2) Observable (you can track metrics to watch for), (3) Actionable (if challenge materializes, you know what to do). Aim for 1-5 challenges across all belief categories. Use challenges to: (1) Risk planning (what if we're wrong? what's plan B?), (2) Monitoring (which metrics should we track?), (3) Intellectual humility (remind team our beliefs are hypotheses, not truths). Update challenges when: New data emerges (counter-evidence appears), Beliefs evolve (new belief, new challenge), Monitoring reveals signals (challenge is materializing - time to pivot?).

belief.description: Reference to the belief being challenged - which core belief (market, user, approach, value, competition) has counter-evidence.

counter_evidence.description: Data or observations that challenge this belief - what would prove it wrong or is trending in opposite direction.

monitoring.description: What to track to validate/invalidate - specific metrics, experiments, or research to watch. Example: 'Track quarterly customer interviews - if 3+ mention wanting horizontal tool (not vertical), revisit vertical focus belief.'

alignment_checks.description: Explicit statements verifying internal consistency across North Star components - ensures purpose, vision, mission, values, and beliefs form a coherent strategic narrative. These checks should be performed during North Star creation and updated during major strategic reviews (annual/biannual).
alignment_checks.$comment: Alignment checks are your coherence test: do all components tell the same story? Good alignment: (1) Purpose informs Vision (aspiration serves purpose), (2) Mission delivers Purpose (operations serve aspiration), (3) Values guide Mission (culture enables execution), (4) Beliefs validate Strategy (assumptions align with approach). Misalignment signals: Purpose says 'democratize' but Mission targets Fortune 500 (misaligned market), Values say 'move fast' but strategy requires 3-year platform buildout (misaligned values-strategy), Beliefs say 'users value speed' but roadmap prioritizes depth features (beliefs don't inform strategy). Use alignment checks in: North Star creation (initial validation), Strategic reviews (annual check-in), Pivots (when changing strategy, verify it aligns with purpose/mission), Board decks (demonstrate strategic coherence). Update alignment statements when: Major components change (new mission, new values), Misalignment discovered (team questions coherence), Strategy evolves (ensure beliefs still support approach).

purpose_vision_alignment.description: How vision serves purpose - explicit statement connecting aspirational goal to eternal reason for existence. Example: 'Vision of "every small business having affordable legal counsel by 2030" serves Purpose of "democratizing access to justice" by making legal services economically accessible to previously underserved segment, addressing economic barrier to justice.'
purpose_vision_alignment.$comment: Purpose-Vision alignment ensures your goal (vision) serves your 'why' (purpose). Good alignment statement: (1) Explicit (clear connection, not implied), (2) Measurable (vision metrics indicate purpose progress), (3) Aspirational (vision is stepping stone to purpose, not endpoint). Format: Vision [goal] serves Purpose [why] by [how achieving vision advances purpose]. Test: If you achieve vision, does purpose meaningfully progress? If no, misaligned. Update when: Vision changes (new goal requires new alignment rationale), Purpose clarifies (better understand why we exist).

mission_purpose_alignment.description: How mission delivers on purpose - explicit statement connecting daily operations to eternal reason. Example: 'Mission of "providing self-service legal documents for SMBs" delivers on Purpose of "democratizing access to justice" by removing gatekeepers (lawyers) and reducing cost barriers (DIY vs full-service), making legal support accessible to businesses that couldn't afford traditional counsel.'
mission_purpose_alignment.$comment: Mission-Purpose alignment ensures what you DO (mission) serves why you EXIST (purpose). Good alignment: (1) Operational (mission is actionable today), (2) Purposeful (activities clearly advance purpose), (3) Scoped (mission is bounded subset of purpose, not 100% overlap). Format: Mission [what we do] delivers Purpose [why] by [mechanism - how activities advance cause]. Test: If you stopped doing mission, would purpose progress stall? If no, mission might not be core to purpose. Update when: Mission evolves (new offerings, new customers), Purpose clarifies (better articulation of 'why').

values_mission_alignment.description: How values enable mission delivery - explicit statement connecting behavioral principles to operational effectiveness. Example: 'Values of "Bias to Action" and "Customer Obsession" enable Mission of self-service legal docs by empowering teams to ship MVPs quickly based on user feedback, iterate rapidly, and prioritize customer pain points over technical elegance - essential for serving price-sensitive SMBs with lean operations.'
values_mission_alignment.$comment: Values-Mission alignment ensures your CULTURE (values) enables your OPERATIONS (mission). Good alignment: (1) Enabling (values help mission succeed), (2) Essential (without these values, mission delivery suffers), (3) Tested (can point to examples where values drove mission success). Format: Values [list 2-3 key values] enable Mission by [how behaviors support delivery]. Test: Do you hire/promote for these values because they predict mission success? If no, values may be aspirational but not aligned. Update when: Mission changes (new delivery model may require different values), Values evolve (culture shifts require new alignment story).

beliefs_inform_strategy.description: How core beliefs validate strategic choices - explicit statement connecting assumptions to approach. Example: 'Belief that "legal market is shifting to value-based pricing" informs Strategy of building ROI measurement into product and training sales to sell outcomes. Belief that "SMBs adopt software saving 5+ hours/week even if UI rough" informs Strategy of MVP-first product development, prioritizing core workflows over polish.'
beliefs_inform_strategy.$comment: Beliefs-Strategy alignment ensures your STRATEGY (how you compete) is grounded in ASSUMPTIONS (beliefs) that can be tested and updated. Good alignment: (1) Evidence-based (beliefs reference data/research), (2) Consequential (if beliefs wrong, strategy should change), (3) Testable (you can monitor whether beliefs hold). Format: Belief that "[assumption]" informs Strategy of [strategic choice] because [logical connection]. Include 1-3 examples mapping beliefs to strategic decisions. Test: If key belief is invalidated, would you change strategy? If no, belief isn't truly informing strategy. Update when: Beliefs change (new evidence), Strategy shifts (new approach requires new belief justification), Post-mortem (strategy failed - which belief was wrong?).
